unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Independent Events A and B
question_text:
Suppose two events, A and B, are independent.
Which of the following statements is/are true?
I. $P(A$ and $B) = P(A) \times P(B)$
II. $P(A|B) = P(A)$
III. $P(A|B) = P(B)$
solution:
Statement I is correct; independent events can be multiplied, so the probability of events A and B happening at the same time is $P(A) \times P(B)$. This rule can be extended to multiple events.

Statement II is correct; by definition of independent events, the probability of A occurring stays the same regardless of whether event B occurs.

Statement III is incorrect; this statement states that the probability of A occurring given that B occurs is equal to the probability of B. Even if events are independent, there is no reason to believe that events A and B have equal probability.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
